list_definition.definition: to take (another person’s property), especially secretly, without permission or legal right

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Thieves broke into the house and stole money and jewellery
He was expelled from the school because he had been stealing (money).

list_definition.mean_english: dành được, lấy được cái gì vụng trộm, lén lút
list_definition.definition: to obtain or take (eg a look, a nap etc) quickly or secretly

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He stole a glance at her.
He stole quietly into the room.

list_ex_of_english: Alternatively, consider the rule allowing the use of force to recapture stolen property or to effectuate reentry upon land.
Five bicycle thieves were arrested, and two men stealing from cars.
Scroremoies testified that he harbored no ill feelings toward the victim and that she had not stolen from him.
Very serious cases of violating moral rules, such as stealing, bullying, and hitting, were seldom discussed.
Such assets are much more easily stolen than traditional factors such as physical capital and land.
Often the craftsmen used raw materials stolen from factories or building sites (building materials, metals, yarn).
Such information can be stolen while in transit or in storage.
He was stolen away by fate for ever...
